I think it’s a good reminder that Thanksgiving isn’t the same holiday for everyone. We all celebrate and/or mourn different things.

So, however you celebrate today, I hope Thanksgiving meant something meaningful to you.

I had so much fun writing the Thanksgiving scene for While We Shatter Apart because the foods are different from what I associated with the holiday. The culture, too, & the way the characters treat meals, is also different.

The Thanksgiving holiday appears in 2 of my books. In the Case of Our Fate ends on Thanksgiving Day. While We Shatter Apart (tbr Fall 2022) begins on Thanksgiving Day.

Not all my characters celebrate Thanksgiving. The ones who do, celebrate the holiday w/ varying traditions.

Parents in YA can be cheerleaders for their kids. As hard as it is to stand on the sidelines, it’s part of their job to let their kids fly solo & make mistakes. So, yeah, my MC has good parents. They’re tough when they need to be, but wise enough to know when to step back.

But hey, YA needs good moms like her. Parents want to protect their children from so much. It’s sad when they feel they aren’t doing that great of a job. But sometimes kids have to be the heroes too. They have to know they’re strong enough to stand against adversity.

My MC has great parents, which was a tough concept to pull off in YA. His mom, especially, is amazing. Having to create a reason why she & most of the other adults couldn’t help was tough. It’s still tough throughout the series when she has to learn to let her kids be the heroes.

I’m 24 now. Attended a Christian University for several years, was a worship leader, and I still cannot tell you the complete order of the books of the Bible. Some people’s gifts do not include memorization. Doesn’t mean I’m going to hell for it 🤷🏻‍♀️

I’m a minister’s granddaughter AND a PK, so total stereotype that I would know the order at 8 years old. For the record, probs didn’t know anything past Exodus. Felt like I was going to hell for this lack of knowledge.

The Sunday school teacher was a tall thin woman with a total strict, Miss Minchin vibe. The other girls had to prove they had memorized the books of the Bible. Teacher decided she would test me too. “All Christians must know the books of the Bible.”

My grandfather was a retired minister, which meant he was constantly guest preaching at random churches. One time, I went with my grandparents and they put me in Sunday school. This church’s Sunday school classrooms were in a completely separate building.
